@markusthoemmes, I've updated the commit. The Gradle exec() method expects an array of arguments instead of a string containing all of the arguments. With the array of arguments, spaces are preserved in the directory path.

@sjfink Sure.  Yes, the command parsing package used by the Go CLI is a bit more forgiving regarding the argument flag positioning.  Is the following syntax expected?  The only restriction is that the CSV sequence set must be a single command line argument, so quote the whole CSV if there's a space in any of the the action names.

```
>wsk action create A --sequence "Hello World,Hello World"
ok: created action A

>wsk action update A --sequence "Hello World,Hello World"
ok: updated action A
```
Would you check if the error is also present in #1023? I changed the way the python CLI's `run`.
@mdeuser yes, I think that's the desired syntax.  Thx.
Looks like the issue is fixed by your PR. However, you have to update the run commands if you want the status output to be displayed correctly.
IPG 249.
@mdeuser, ready for review.

We decided that an error in the sequence would stop downstream ones from running.  The idea though is that getting the activation for this composite would include some message indicating abnormal termination for the seq as a whole.

After testing log limits today, I have opened a new issue with docker as there is still a security vulnerability with log sizes in docker 1.12. Linking to it here:

https://github.com/docker/docker/issues/25930

I'd like to support ECA (event condition action) cleanly if we can.   

i.e. if C then foo.

I'd like to implement this as a sequence C -> foo, where C tests a boolean condition and passes through its parameters if true, and somehow aborts if false.    However the "abort" in this case would not really be an error, but a normal "false" condition.

Proposal: if an action returns "null", it is considered "success", but terminates a sequence.
Null being "{}"?
It must be since actions must return a Json object.
Yes,   "{}".    We can have "return null" be sugar for "return {}" maybe.
@rabbah, I don't believe `rule update` currently has the `--enable` flag.
@mdeuser, I believe @csantanapr took care of this one.
Good to hear: Apparently the log size issue is fixed with docker 1.13.

Initial benchmark testing on Docker 1.12.1 using Kernel 4.4.0-28 looks encouraging:

```
Server Version: 1.12.1
Kernel Version: 4.4.0-28-generic

Storage Driver: overlay
Backing Filesystem: extfs
CPUs: 4

Full     = docker run, pause, unpause, rm
No pause = docker run, rm
Skip rm  = docker run, pause, unpause  (for testing)

Table shows the rate (per sec) of a docker sequence.  Measured with 5 iterations per thread.  Error count in parens.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
            1 thread   2 threads (lock)   2 threads     Speedup      3 threads     Speedup
Full         2.236          2.392          3.706          1.66        4.147          1.85
No pause     2.554                         3.982          1.56        4.452          1.74
Skip rm      4.334                         6.857          1.58        6.727          1.55
```

The numbers are comparable to Docker 1.11 and about 50% better than Docker 1.9,
This is a single-node benchmark, not a load test on a distributed system yet. Will conduct that now.
Regarding the log size issue, the PR to fix it went in already. See #22982. So as @domdom82 said, fixed in 1.13.

Regarding the /tmp filesystem there is an alternative way besides tmpfs, although I would only use it as a last resort. I only mention it here for reference.
1. Make an empty file to hold the tmp fs. (1G in this example. takes about 1.5 sec)  
   `
   dd if=/dev/zero of=/tmp/tmpfs.bin bs=1M count=1024
   `
2. Make a filesystem in the file (ext4 in this example. takes 0.1 sec)  
   `
   mkfs.ext4 -F -v /tmp/tmpfs.bin
   `
3. Mount the filesystem locally on the docker host  
   `
   mount /tmp/tmpfs.bin /mnt/tmp/ -t ext4 -o loop,rw,noexec,nosuid
   `
4. Export the filesystem to the docker container (that read-only otherwise)  
   `
   docker run --read-only -v /mnt/tmp:/tmp -it ubuntu bash
   `

This has the one advantage that it does not eat memory.
However there are multiple drawbacks to this:
- Loopbacks are very slow. We don't expect a lot of load here but still.
- Massive overhead. The invoker will have to keep track of all those loopback files. It will need to create them, mkfs them, mount them and clean them up during gc later.
- Performance loss to actually make the files (dd-ing alone takes about 1.5 secs on top of the docker run command. 0.8 secs for 512M files)

In contrast, tmpfs costs next to no time to create and is immediately destroyed when the container ends.

With docker 1.12 there is even a CLI option to use tmpfs right away:

```
docker run --read-only --tmpfs /tmp:rw,noexec,nosuid,size=64M -it ubuntu bash
```

Simple as that.

@rabbah - Updating a non-existent action does not result in failure though.  Is this expected?

```
>wsk action update doesnotexist --sequence "Hello World,Hello World"
ok: updated action doesnotexist
```

The PUT request URL is `[PUT]   https://openwhisk.ng.bluemix.net/api/v1/namespaces/mdeuser_dev/actions/doesnotexist?overwrite=true`
Semantics of update are create if it doesn't exist else update.

I think this behavior may lead to some confusion... a typo in the action name being updated.  We can enforce this in the CLI if needed.

Validation of the existence of the supplied sequence action names being handled by #995

@csantanapr i have updated the PR as you have suggested, i.e. to mention that the username field can be your GitHub organization name, too.

[update] never mind, reverted based on @bjustin-ibm's comments

@starpit Sorry for chiming in late, but @csantanapr's suggestion about the `username` field is not correct. Please review these new comments I just posted:

https://github.com/openwhisk/openwhisk/pull/1103#discussion_r75861966

The API method to create is a PUT. It is common for PUT to create a resource if it doesn't exist. We use ?overwrite true to explicitly create/override. I know from demos and use cases I've observed it's more convenient to use update than create with the deployment scripts. 

-r

@lehoanganh, as commented above, with one instance of the code pulled in, one deployment of OpenWhisk is going to be there. As such, it should be part of global deployment, and it doesn't buy us anything moving the checks to under environment, just so that its easier to override

What is the Go version change?
@mdeuser, here is a blog regarding the newest release of Go: https://blog.golang.org/go1.7-binary-size. The latest release focuses heavily on the reduction of binary size.

Also why do we want to confuse someone who is going to deploy this as to how many places this user has to be changed? The logic currently looks in one place, and if we change it to a convoluted logic for looking for user defined in multiple palces - its going to be confusing for someone not familiar with code anatomy - in my view this doesnt buy as anything substantive
LGTM

Since we can still use the global `group_vars/all` in our deployment and our `docker.user` unlikely to change anytime soon per environment I tend to agree with @animeshsingh for now. If we experience problems later, this is not going to be hard to change anyway. So LGTM.

With --pids-limit coming in Docker 1.11 and Kernel 4.3 we no longer need nproc ulimit. This makes this problem much easier to handle as we don't need different user ids for every container. Instead I suggest we use an unprivileged user id like "nobody" to run the containers and see where we land.
is there anything more you need from me on this?
it means, for each invoking docker action, invoker will try to pull the image, and doesn't care if the image is there locally or not?
Yes, that's semantically preserving what it did before. Docker will fast forward though, and almost immediatly notice that the layers are already there.
2 seconds for the check ;)
Checking the image manually whether it is there or not does cost some time as well :)
as discussed, if `docker run` also does the pull for us, why should we have to pull the image by ourselves ;)

@lzbj, the error is the result of propertySetCmd() trying to access client.Config.BaseURL. Since the call to setup the client configuration was removed from the mentioned command, an invalid memory address error occurs because clientConfig is nil.
@lehoanganh because an explicit `pull` at least checks, if the latest version is around.
For bookkeeping sake, the above mentioned `--full`, and `---serviceguid` issues have been fixed.

> wsk package create - The Go CLI has a --service_guid argument, the Python CLI does not
> wsk package update - The Go CLI has a --service_guid argument, the Python CLI does not

These should not be in the go-cli, they are entirely Bluemix specific.

> is there anything more you need from me on this?

@starpit I think it would be great to mention how the `repository` value can optionally include the organization. Apart from that, this LGTM.

how about we put this in the sampleInput? right now, it reads `"repository": "WhiskRepository"`

how about changing this to `"repository": "[myOrganization/]myRepository"`
@csantanapr PG1 280 is now clean. here is the corresponding openwhisk-catalog item: https://github.com/openwhisk/openwhisk-catalog/pull/122

The square brackets were (I'm supposing) intended by Carlos to show that it is optional, and is not actually part of the value. In this case, the sample input should be `"repository": "myOrganization/myRepository"`.

However, I worry that using this sample input might imply that the organization is required.

How about changing the `repository` description to 

> The name of your GitHub repository. Optionally this can be prefixed with the GitHub organization followed by a slash (e.g. myOrganization/myRepository).

Too long?
